ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to speak moderate spanish.

I became more comfortable with talking during this course. I learned more verb conjugations and more vocabulary. It was a pretty basic Spanish 2 course, good for anyone who is already fairly comfortable with the language.
I became more fluent in Spanish and learned the past and future tenses.
I learned grammar skills, conjugations, and improved writing and speaking. I also grew my vocabulary.
I learned how to communicate more effectively in Spanish and grammar. I also learned more about the culture in South American Spanish-speaking countries.

Basic grammar and vocabulary like the subjunctive, indicative, past perfect, present perfect, commands, por and para. Practice reading, writing, and speaking. Learn about the culture of Spanish speaking countries through presentations.
I learned a lot of new vocabulary and refreshed my knowledge of grammar rules. I also learned more about culture in Spanish speaking countries.
Course introduces subjunctive mood in the present tense, irregular preterites, commands, and the future tense. Vocab. topics include chores, nature, celebrations, and health to name a few.
This course greatly improved my speaking and listening skills in Spanish. I also got better at composing writing and thinking on the spot.
I learned a lot about spanish grammar

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Weaknesses: WAY too much work

I would have liked to go over grammar concepts in class more, rather than just vocabulary. I also would have liked if we were given a clearer rubric of grading. For many assignments the grade we received felt very arbitrary. Also when we submitted writing we were not told exactly what was wrong with it which was not helpful.   However, we had a lot of practice speaking and presenting which was good.
A strength of this course is that you learn a lot in a short amount of time but that requires a lot of work, which sometimes amount to busywork.

Some strengths were quick grading, a comprehensive and readable textbook, and engaging in class assignments. I also appreciated asynchronous Wednesdays. I didn't love memorizing presentations, but I don't necessarily see that as a weakness.

One strength was having an asynchronous day to work separately on our Spanish work. A weakness was the amount of memorization needed for weekly presentations when memorizing specific Spanish sentences is not helpful for retention or for becoming a better Spanish speaker.

Strengths of the course are that we had a consistent schedule where we did presentations every Friday. We also practiced speaking a lot through Lingua meeting which was helpful. Another strength was professor Maripaz who was super kind and understanding throughout the semester. Weaknesses of the class are that it can become repetitive at times.

A strength of the course was the homework and textbook. Past Spanish courses I have taken did not give effective homework but I felt the assignments in this class were extremely helpful. We learned new concepts on our own at home and practiced them the next day in class. A weakness of the class was the lack of access to corrections on the homework. Many times the correct answer was simply given without any explanation if a question was answered incorrectly.

The public speaking assignments could be a lot of stress for students at times. Mixing these up by having students sometimes write poems or songs might make this easier. VLH assignments are fantastic.

Strengths: This course was remarkably organized. Grades would be uploaded in a super timely manner, and the syllabus helped us know what the assignments were way in advance. Also, class time included lots of speaking practice, which greatly improved my language skills. I liked the diversity in assignments that kept anything from being too old + the amount of notice we got to complete everything. I also loved that Wednesdays were asynchronous because it made the everyday classes much more manageable.
Weaknesses: People come into the class with varying degrees of exposure/comfort with Spanish, and I don't think this was accommodated super well. The professor would ask questions, and people who were good at comprehending Spanish would answer while others were left in the dust. As someone whose background with the language was very shaky, I would have liked if the professor could have found ways we could still participate even if we were not as fast as the other students. Also, there was a big emphasis on memorization in this class. We had to memorize and recite lots of presentations, which I don't think is the most helpful way to learn a language. This course was also very expensive with a $100+ textbook and LinguaMeetings that cost $40. The LinguaMeetings particularly were not worth the additional financial burden.

I thought there were many areas for improvement in this course. I do not think that the online VHL homework should have been graded for accuracy because this put the pressure to use other resources to do perfectly on it rather than using it to test our knowledge and allow us to make mistakes in order to learn. I felt we were severely lacking practice in grammar. We often would read about tenses in our textbook but really did not get enough practice whatsoever in class.  I think there were too many reading and culture activities in class and we never got to have the correct practice actually speaking and writing the language. More grammar drills and lessons would have been helpful. I also really did not like how we were forced to memorize for our presentations, this created a lot of unnecessary stress. Lastly,  I wish there were smaller quizzes on vocabulary and grammar rather than three big tests that encompassed a lot of material each.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would recommend. It wasn't hard if you have taken Spanish before, especially if you took it throughout high school. It is a good review course that helps to cement conjugations, sentence structure, etc. into your head. All in all, the workload was reasonable and it never felt too hard.
Yes, if you want to become more proficient in Spanish in a short amount of time but be prepared for a decent amount of work.
Yes I think it improved my Spanish and I didn't think it was too difficult.
If you have to take language sure.
Yes, if you want to practice Spanish consistently.

I would recommend the course to another student if they had minimal experience with Spanish. The course thoroughly goes over many of the basic grammar concepts that I learned previously. It also incorporates lots of new vocabulary.

If you have placed into spanish 2, I recommend waiting a while and starting at spanish 1. If you do you only need to go to spanish 3 instead of spanish 4. College language classes are not as fun as high school ones tend to be, and even if you like language learning the pace is aggressive.

This course is fine if you need to get a language requirement out of the way. It is not particularly fun or interesting, and it meets every day except asynchronous Wednesdays. But, you leave the course with improved language skills which are well worth it.
no, but it's a language requirement so it's not necessarily a choice
